title: What can Australia learn from Draghi's reign at the ECB?
text:
Did the nationalised ECB elixir work to cure Europe? In the chart we see a pre-crisis link between inflation and growth – GDP peaks are followed by inflation peaks. The central bank balance sheet sat at around 11 per cent of GDP and had no evident role in this. Since then, the ECB balance sheet has been raised in three stages to 40 per cent of Europe’s GDP – the third phase being the largest. However, even this unprecedented dose of the medicine was not enough to avoid inflation falling below the 2 per cent target. The recovery was weak, and now GDP growth is fading once more.

So, QE doesn’t work very well. Nor should we expect it to. After all, the interbank market is a ‘between-the-banks’ kind of thing. It has no direct links with real savers and investors.

Since the exchange rate is the relative price of two monies, QE might work as a devaluation tool (though this motivation is always denied). Mario Draghi was beaten to it by the US and Japan. AP

So, how did the benefits and costs of ‘dosing up’ on QE compare?

Did Draghi save the euro? Well sort of. It’s still there with all its basic problems. Germany doesn’t want to expand fiscal policy and issue deficit bonds. It runs budget surpluses. Its current account surplus and capital inflows from other European countries (that want to hold safe German assets) is not matched by any equal German demand to acquire foreign assets. With no exchange rates to adjust supply and demand, the gap is plugged by Germany via official financing between central banks.

This has resulted in the Bundesbank acquiring claims on other euro central banks to the tune of €900 billion (and rising). It earns nothing or even negative returns on these balances. It also risks not getting its money back were some members to leave the euro one day. This state-of-affairs is one of the main sources of tension inside the ECB Governing Council.

The policy also entrenches the euro as the main cause of Europe’s woes. The euro forces competitive adjustment through labour markets, and there is no fiscal union to facilitate cross-country compensation for losing households in the south.

Did the ECB manage to improve the euro’s competitiveness? Central bank liabilities are ‘money’ (currency and the reserve accounts of banks). Since the exchange rate is the relative price of two monies, QE might work as a devaluation tool (though this motivation is always denied). The trouble for Draghi was that the US and (especially) Japan beat him to it. With everyone doing the same thing, the ECB policy only managed to keep the real value of the euro stable. In 2019 it is where it was when Draghi took office.

But it’s worse than that. QE has the unintended consequence of under-pricing of risk –the very cause of the last crisis. QE lowers the risk premium on securities in the economy. If one reduces private holdings of securities in favour of safe cash, then bond risk premiums fall. Combined with low short-term interest rates, yield curves can invert. Long-term rates can become negative. Imagine! Paying the government for the privilege of lending to it.

Some central banks think all this is a good thing for real investment and growth. No, it isn’t. Investors are forced into equities and high-credit-risk assets driving down yields there too. This is secondary market price action. As I have explained before in these pages, this raises no new capital for investment. Only IPOs and primary bond markets can do that.

QE pushes up asset prices, encourages leverage, destroys the interbank market and takes pressure off governments to act on fiscal policy. Draghi’s last speech passes this last important task to his successor. Madame Lagarde must understand some of the lessons of the Draghi years.

Australia’s exchange rate works just fine and we never had Europe’s banking disaster. As our growth fades too (for different reasons) the last thing we should be doing is combining Germany’s fiscal thinking (surpluses) with the ECB’s QE philosophy.

We must hope that our politicians are thoughtfully pondering some of the lessons of the Draghi years.
description: QE did not really work and is full of unintended consequences. We should leave it well alone.
